explanation: detect_process_cpu_core_count contains no for loops itself, but the MISRA rule treats the behaviour of any function called inside a for-statement as part of that for-loop’s body. To determine compliance you must therefore inspect all direct and transitive callees for any for-loops (and whether those loops’ clauses or bodies use/modify objects that would violate the rule). • get_cpu_core_count — direct callee: inspect its implementation for any for loops and side effects that could interact with loop counters or loop-control flags. • mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count — direct callee: it may contain or call functions that use for-loops; its behaviour could be part of a loop body in other contexts. • detect_cpu_core_count — callee of get_cpu_core_count: include to cover transitive for-loops and side effects. • mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_w32_ — transitive callees of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count: include each because any for-loops or modifications they perform may affect analysis of loop well-formedness when these functions are used inside loop bodies. Note: standard I/O functions (printf, fprintf, stderr) are not relevant to checking the for-loop formation rule, so they are omitted.
